title: 110_hr2460
content: The "Federal Energy Price Protection Act" prohibits suppliers from unreasonably increasing prices for crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates in areas covered by a Presidential proclamation. Justifiable price increases are allowed under certain circumstances. The "Federal Energy Price Protection Act" allows for justifiable price increases for crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates under specific conditions, including increases in wholesale costs, replacement costs, operational costs, and market conditions. Other factors considered include market equilibrium and competitive pricing. The Federal Energy Price Protection Act allows for justifiable price increases for crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates based on additional costs or risks incurred by the seller. SEC. 4. EMERGENCY PROCLAMATIONS AND ORDERS. The President can issue emergency proclamations for abnormal market disruptions, specifying duration, reason, and geographic area. Proclamations are limited to 30 days, renewable for another 30 days. The President can issue emergency proclamations for abnormal market disruptions, limited to 30 days and may apply to a period of not more than 7 days before the occurrence of the event. SEC. 5. ENFORCEMENT BY FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION. The Federal Trade Commission is empowered to prevent suppliers from engaging in unfair or deceptive acts or practices as defined in this Act. Violators are subject to penalties and entitled to privileges and immunities under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Federal Trade Commission Act provisions are included in this Act, and the FTC must create regulations within 180 days to enforce it. SEC. 6. PENALTIES. Civil Penalty: Suppliers violating this Act may face civil penalties of up to $500,000 for small business marketers of gasoline and up to $5,000,000 for other suppliers. Penalties will be assessed similarly to those under the Federal Trade Commission Act. Multiple offenses and mitigating factors will be considered in penalty assessment. The Act imposes civil penalties of up to $500,000 for small business marketers of gasoline and up to $5,000,000 for other suppliers. Violations may result in fines of up to $1,000,000, imprisonment for up to 2 years, or both. Each violation of price increase during a proclaimed period is considered a single violation. The criminal penalty for violations under the Act includes fines of up to $1,000,000, imprisonment for a maximum of 2 years, or both. Enforcement can only be done through a criminal action brought by the Attorney General or other Department of Justice officer. SEC. 7. Amounts from fines and penalties go to Consumer Relief Trust Fund for Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program. SEC. 8. Definitions. The Act defines "abnormal market disruption" as a situation where there is a reasonable likelihood of increased prices for crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates due to various factors like extreme weather, natural disasters, or civil disorder. It also defines "supplier" as any person involved in selling or distributing these products. The term "replacement costs" refers to the costs incurred by a supplier for crude oil, gasoline, or other petroleum distillates, including storage, transportation, and delivery costs. "Unconscionable amount" signifies a significant price increase for crude oil for a supplier under section 2 of the Act. The Act defines "unconscionable amount" as a significant price increase for crude oil, gasoline, or petroleum distillates that substantially exceeds the average prices in the area and from competitors during the emergency proclamation period. The emergency proclamation applies and cannot be justified by considering the factors described in section 3. The Act will take effect when the Federal Trade Commission issues a final rule under section 5(c) and publishes it in the Federal Register.
